docs.lead_paragraph: For the elderly and disabled people of this weary looking city surrounded by cornfields, Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield's Medicare health maintenance organization was a godsend. It bought a motorized scooter for Ronnie Hines, who has diabetes and multiple sclerosis. It diagnosed Dorothy Kloecker's shallow breathing disorder, after many tests, and helped her to control it with daily two-hour walks through the hilly cemetery. It removed the benign but disconcerting lump in Rosie Stelzner's jaw.

headline.main: End of H.M.O. for the Elderly Brings Dismay in Rural Ohio

docs.abstract: Elderly and disabled residents in 19 rural Ohio counties are dismayed by anouncement by Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield that its Medicare health maintenance orgn is being discontinued as of Dec 31, just year and half after it started; decision affects 18,235 elderly and disabled clients; Anthem provided kind of aggressive prevention-oriented care that Congress and other health planners envisioned when they opened up 33-year-old Medicare program to HMO's and other forms of managed care; Anthem officials say they their company, which successfully operated a Medicare HMO around Cincinnati, about 75 miles south, for three years, had found itself over-extended, over-subscribed and under-paid by Federal Govt; Anthem's retreat, like those of other HMO's recently, casts shadow over decision by Congress and Clinton Administration to steer more of nation's retirees into managed care; photo; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Brian J. LeClair (Op-Ed, July 28) thinks that Congress should begin to worry about the growing ranks of uninsured. But I didn't see many articles by representatives of the insurance industry on the need for insurance portability laws in 1996, or the children's health insurance legislation last year.

docs.lead_paragraph: Tension and fear hover over the strawberry fields of the Coastal Berry Company here like the morning fog. In the last few weeks, the lush fields outside of this small city 70 miles south of San Francisco have become a battleground in an increasingly nasty and nationally significant two-and-a-half-year struggle by the United Farm Workers to unionize the men and women who pick the sweet red berries, often for short pay and long hours: Their backs bent, their heads down, their hopes low.

headline.main: A Union Vote Sows Bitterness in California Strawberry Fields

docs.abstract: Lush fields outside Watsonville, Calif, have become battleground in increasingly nasty and nationally significant two-and-half-year struggle by United Farm Workers to unionize men and women who pick strawberries, often for short pay and long hours; since July 1, there have been threats, arrests, beatings of UFW supporters, a disputed union election that rival group won, a one-day strike to protest election and hearing at State Capitol into entire bitter harvest; UFW says it will file legal papers with California Agricultural Labor Relations Board, seeking to throw out results of union vote at Coastal Berry, nation's largest strawberry grower; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In asking ''What About a Bill of Rights for the Uninsured?'' (Op-Ed, July 28), Brian J. LeClair raises an important question about the 40 million Americans who have no health insurance coverage but falls far short of a reasonable answer. A solution can be found abroad: all other industrialized Western democracies guarantee affordable health care to all their people. They pay less per person than we do and, according to United Nations data, have longer life expectancies and lower infant mortality rates. These countries eliminate the large portion of payments Americans waste on the profits, inefficiencies and marketing costs of insurance companies and for-profit health maintenance organizations.

headline.main: Universal Care, Yes, but Patient's Rights First; When Profits Go

docs.abstract: Letter from Robert S Rochlin prompted by July 28 Op-Ed article by Brian J LeClair says all other industrialized Western democracies guarantee affordable health care to all their people by eliminating portion of payments Americans waste on insurance companies and for-profit health maintenance organizations (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Brian J. LeClair (Op-Ed, July 28), a health insurance executive, is right that neither Republican nor Democratic patients' rights legislation deals with the worst failing in our health insurance arrangements: the lack of coverage for 40 million people. But he is trying to distract us from the misconduct the bills do address. For instance, he claims that allowing patients to go outside a network ''cuts right to the heart of managed care's ability to cut costs and make health care affordable.'' But plans that offer this option, as he admits, pay sharply reduced benefits to patients who see doctors not on the lists.

headline.main: Universal Care, Yes, but Patients' Rights First

docs.abstract: Letter from John W Bush says Brian J LeClair, in his July 28 Op-Ed article, makes valuable criticisms of patients' rights legislation now under consideration, but his real aim is to distract consumers from misconduct bills do address (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''What About a Bill of Rights for the Uninsured?'' (Op-Ed, July 28): In the past year I have spend $50,000 for treatment of a disease my health maintenance organization has refused to cover. It has been a year of suffering from the disease, fear of running out of money before getting better and stress from waging the fight with my H.M.O. Because rules are unreasonably burdensome to someone who is ill, the H.M.O. won.

headline.main: Universal Care, Yes, but Patient's Rights First; Paying for Lobbyists

docs.abstract: Letter from Elaine Matto says health insurance bills include costs of advertising, lobbyists, political donations and lawyers, all used to manipulate public opinion and influence politicians so that responsibility to patients can be evaded (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Brian J. LeClair (Op-Ed, July 28) argues that the Democratic health reform bill would do more damage than the Republicans' bill because the Democratic plan would drive up insurance rates by allowing clients to sue health maintenance organizations. This ignores the problem addressed by the right-to-sue proposal, which is to force H.M.O.'s to act more responsibly when deciding whether to deny care.

headline.main: Universal Care, Yes, but Patient's Rights First; The Right to Sue

docs.lead_paragraph: We truly live in wonderful times, but now and then when Old Devil Skeptic jumps on my back, he starts me asking myself questions. Here are several I asked just this morning. 1. Scientists who work with genes have just cloned some mice. It was big news, but can somebody tell me: Why does the world need more mice?

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite signs that economic growth is slowing sharply, wages and benefits are climbing a bit faster than a year ago. The Labor Department's employment cost index -- a broad gauge of compensation trends closely watched by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, and other policy makers -- rose nine-tenths of 1 percent this spring, slightly more than the seven-tenths of 1 percent increase in the winter. For the 12 months ended in June, pay for all civilian workers, including government workers, rose 3.5 percent, up from 2.8 percent in the previous year.

headline.main: Labor Costs Rose Slightly In the Spring

docs.abstract: Labor Department's employment cost index, broad gauge of compensation trends watched by Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan, rose nine-tenths of 1 percent this spring, slightly more than seven-tenths of 1 percent increase in winter; for 12 months ended in June, pay for all civilian workers rose 3.5 percent, up from 2.8 percent in previous year; latest reading is not likely to provoke Greenspan to raise interest rates; Conference Board reports that help-wanted advertising index rose to 91 in June from 90 in May and 88 a year ago; Labor Department says new claims for unemployment insurance dropped to 304,000 last week from 317,000 the week before; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Is it time for investors to stick a toe in? The stock of Oxford Health Plans, the troubled managed-care company, has long been down and out, after plunging last year when the company told investors to expect an enormous loss. Now, the stock has again fallen precipitously, losing nearly half its sharply reduced value in the last few weeks. It closed on Nasdaq yesterday at $8.4325, after touching a new low of $7.375 during the previous day's trading.

headline.main: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Troubled Health Plan's Stock Price Ills

docs.abstract: Market Place column on continued decline in price of stock of Oxford Health Plans; says Oxford's shares, which traded above $20 earlier this year, closed on July 30 at $8.4325, after touching new low of $7.375 during previous day's trading; graph (M)
